If Jtest is complaining, the=
n is it REALLY valid and thoroughly tested code? I'm not trying to bait you=

meter values in methods

Agreed. =
:-)

>The motto 'Garbage in Garbage out' still applies in this case. As an
=

Not agreed. GIGO is only for non-robust code. I think that "Garbage In" sh=
ould cause appropriate guard conditions to be triggered and an appropriate =
response to be generated NPE or IAE (your choice). For anything other than =
the most trivial of code, I do not want to ever contribute to "Garbage Out"=
. As developers we usually have no control over the many potential ways tha=
t our code could be used, but we do have control over how it responds.

>an=
alogy you might say that the software application is like a car
>exposing c=
ertain interfaces that must be handled in a specific way.
>If you bypass th=
ese interfaces you can get unexpected results, no
>sensible car testing aut=
hority would put a burning piece of cloth into
>the gastank and would repor=
t the following explosing a 'serious
>defect' found through a dynamic test.=


Actually, I'm sure that contingency is addressed by the automotive indust=
ry. Now bringing fire near any body of petrol is bad, but there are ways to=
 reduce the likelihood of a bad thing. Baffles in the tube leading to the p=
etrol tank are an example of trying to provide hardware guard conditions.

=
>I do not want to resolve all 'dubious' runtime exceptions reported by
>JTe=
st ! 

Any decent tool should allow you to turn off inappropriate tests.

>=
If you are working in life threatening devices using Java such as
>Simon yo=
u might need this JTest behaviour but I think 99% of all Java
>developers w=
ork on non life threatening applications
>(except when you are running behi=
nd schedule and your boss want's your

Fortunat=
ely, I don't work with anything too dangerous these days. I used to work in=
 a Radiography department, so I am aware of the issues there. The project t=
hat I am winding up now is not life threatening, but because of volume, it =
does need to be very fast and very accurate or the CEO will be asking why i=
t is failing to process about 2000 shipments an hour! (Not a conversation t=
hat I ever want to have!) I still think that it's appropriate to "harden" o=
ur code to handle the unexpected.

This is the concept of "graceful degreda=
tion". A web browser is a very good example of this .... a lot of web pages=
 have awful HTML and yet most of them display acceptably, because the brows=
er takes what it's given and does the best it can with it. A browser cannot=
 throw an exception, but it can try to render what it's given. All software=
 should do the best it can with what it's given or when possible reject una=
cceptable inputs.
